questiontext.text:
Challenge question: Logarithmic spiral

In this question we are going to use some simple matrix transformations to create some fun plots.

A point p = (x, y) in two space can be represented as a column vector, i.e. a 2 x 1 matrix

\[ p = \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix} \]

 Such a point can be rotated counter clockwise \( \theta \) radians about the origin by multiplying on the left by the matrix: 
\[ \begin{bmatrix} \cos(\theta) & -\sin(\theta)\\ \sin(\theta) & \cos(\theta) \end{bmatrix} \]

For example we could represent the rotation of the point p = (1, 2) by \( \frac{\pi}{2} \) (90º) counter clockwise as:

\[\begin{bmatrix} 0 && -1 \\ 1 && 0 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} -2 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} \]

Furthermore, a point can be scaled by \( s \) with respect to the origin by multiplying on the left by the matrix:

\[ \begin{bmatrix} s & 0\\ 0 & s\end{bmatrix} \]

If we apply a rotation transformation then a scaling transformation to a point it can rotated about the origin and moved slightly further away from the origin. If we do this repeatedly and draw a line through the points we get a logarithmic spiral.

Using the method mentioned above, write a function plot_log_spiral(n, theta_degs, scalar) that plots a logarithmic spiral with n points. Each point should be rotated theta_degs (degrees) then scaled by scalar at each step. The first point in the plot should be the point \( (1, 0) \). 

Notes:

  • You are allowed to use loops and comprehensions.
  • The above plot was made with the call plot_log_spiral(505, 5, 1.01)
  • The title should be the same as in the plot above, i.e. of the form "Logarithmic Spiral: n = {n}, rotation = {theta in radians to 2 decimal places}, scalar = {scalar to 2 decimal places}"
  • The x and y axes should be labelled "x" and "y" as in the plot above.
  • Each function in your answer must have no more than 10 statements; you will need to write at least one helper function.

Experiment with different parameters and see what cool plots you can generate!

question.answer:
{"answer_code":[""""Plot a logarithmic spiral.
 Point are represented as 2D array column vectors throughout 
 (so broadcasting isn't used).
"""
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

def transformation_matrix(theta_rads, scalar):
 """Returns a 2 x 2 transformation matrix for the given rotation (in radians)
 and scaling parameters.
 """
 rotation = np.array([[np.cos(theta_rads), -np.sin(theta_rads)],
 [np.sin(theta_rads), np.cos(theta_rads)]])
 scale = scalar * np.identity(2)
 return scale @ rotation


def spiral_array(n, theta_rads, scalar):
 """Returns n x 2 array in which rows represent points forming a logarithmic 
 spiral with the given rotation (in radians) and scaling parameters.
 """
 p = np.array([[1], [0]]) # A column vector
 trans = transformation_matrix(theta_rads, scalar)
 spiral = np.zeros((n, 2)) # Rows will be the points on the spiral.
 spiral[0] = p.T # Transpose point to fit spiral array.
 for i in range(1, n):
 p = trans @ p
 spiral[i] = p.T
 return spiral


def plot_log_spiral(n, theta_degs, scalar):
 """Plots a logarithmic spiral with the given number of points n,
 rotation (in degrees) theta_degs, and scaling scalar.
 """
 theta_rads = np.radians(theta_degs)
 spiral = spiral_array(n, theta_rads, scalar)
 axes = plt.axes()
 axes.plot(spiral[:, 0], spiral[:, 1])
 title = f"Logarithmic Spiral: n = {n}, rotation = {theta_rads:.2f}, scalar = {scalar:.2f}"
 axes.set_title(title)
 axes.set_xlabel('x')
 axes.set_ylabel('y')
 axes.grid(True)
 plt.show()"],"test_code":[""],"show_hide":[""],"prefix_ans":["1"]}
